Clinical Variables





















Advice

Consult with clinical oncologists, breast surgeons, and obstetricians. Pregnancy does not adversely affect long-term survival after breast cancer treatment. Most women should wait at least 2 years after treatment before conception. The majority of pregnancies after breast cancer proceed to live birth, with a small increased risk of miscarriage. Women can be reassured concerning the risk of malformations in children conceived after treatment for breast cancer. Pregnancy following breast cancer should be jointly supervised by the obstetrician, oncologist, and breast surgeon. Women can breastfeed from the unaffected breast without increasing the risk of recurrence. The effect of breast cancer treatment on fertility should be discussed with all women of reproductive age diagnosed with breast cancer.
